title: Lattice Document System Implementation
description:
Lattice is a unified knowledge base and task tracking system built on markdown files stored in git repositories, with SQLite providing an ephemeral index for query performance.

## Core Innovation

Lattice treats markdown documents as first-class database entities while maintaining full git compatibility and human readability. Documents can exist anywhere in a project hierarchy, colocated with relevant code, and are identified by their `lattice-id` YAML annotation rather than filesystem location.

## Design Philosophy

- **Document Atomicity**: 500-line soft limit encourages focused documentation
- **Git as Source of Truth**: SQLite serves exclusively as a performance cache
- **Bulletproof Self-Healing**: Graceful error recovery with clear human-readable messages
- **No Background Daemons**: Maintenance operations run opportunistically before commands

## Key Features

- YAML frontmatter for metadata (lattice-id, name, description, task tracking)
- ID-based linking with automatic path resolution via `lat fmt`
- Task tracking (bug/feature/task/chore) with blocking/blocked-by dependencies
- Filesystem-based state: open tasks vs `.closed/` directory
- Claude Skill integration (documents with `skill: true` become Skills)
- Full-text search via FTS5
- Comprehensive linting and validation

## Connection Setup

On every connection open, execute:
- `PRAGMA journal_mode = WAL`
- `PRAGMA synchronous = NORMAL`
- `PRAGMA temp_store = MEMORY`
- `PRAGMA mmap_size = 268435456` (256MB)

- After bulk operations: `PRAGMA wal_checkpoint(TRUNCATE)`
- Index location: `.lattice/index.sqlite` (gitignored)

- WAL mode: concurrent readers/writers, 30-60% faster commits
- Synchronous NORMAL: safe with WAL, acceptable for rebuildable cache
- Memory-mapped I/O: set mmap_size to expected index size
- Disable mmap on network filesystems (set to 0)

- Connection open + configure: <5ms
- Document lookup by ID: <1ms

Implement L2 content cache in `content_cache.rs`.

## Purpose

L2 cache for document body content, reducing filesystem reads for frequently
accessed documents. L1 cache is the OS filesystem cache; this provides an
additional layer within SQLite.

## Content Cache Table

| Column | Type | Description |
|--------|------|-------------|
| document_id | TEXT PK | Lattice ID |
| content | TEXT | Full document body |
| content_hash | TEXT | SHA-256 for invalidation |
| accessed_at | TEXT | Last access timestamp |
| file_mtime | INTEGER | File mtime at cache time |

## Cache Policy

- Validate entries by comparing `file_mtime` against current filesystem mtime
- Stale entries are refreshed on access (read-through cache)
- Evict least-recently-accessed entries when cache exceeds 100 documents
- Cache hit avoids syscall overhead for hot documents

## Core Operations

- Get cached content (with mtime validation)
- Put content in cache
- Invalidate specific document
- Eviction sweep (remove oldest entries over limit)
- Clear entire cache

## Usage by Commands

- `lat show`: Avoids repeated file reads for multiple documents
- `lat search`: Result snippets without reading entire files
- Template composition: Caches ancestor document content

# INTRODUCTION

You are implementing the Lattice document management tool.

Primary design doc: @rules_engine/docs/lattice/lattice_design.md

Please complete exactly one task, provided below. Please put the bead ID at the
start of your commit message in [square brackets].

# YOUR TASK

<!-- BEADS_TASK_BODY_START -->
Implement command dispatch to route parsed arguments to handler functions.

## Scope

- Match parsed commands to handler functions
- Thread context (GitOps, Index) through handlers
- Implement startup operations hook (runs before each command)
- Map results to exit codes per error handling spec
- Implement hidden `--no-startup` flag for debugging

## Startup Operations Hook

Per @rules_engine/docs/lattice/appendix_startup_operations.md:
- Index reconciliation
- Skill symlink sync
- Claim cleanup
- Log rotation
- Performance budget: <100ms total; emit debug log if exceeded

## Implementation Notes

- Create a `CommandContext` struct holding shared state (GitOps, Index, Config)
- Each command handler receives context and returns `LatticeResult<()>`
- Convert `LatticeError` to appropriate exit codes

## Reference Documentation

- @rules_engine/docs/lattice/appendix_startup_operations.md
- @rules_engine/docs/lattice/appendix_error_handling.md (exit codes)
- @rules_engine/docs/lattice/appendix_cli_structure.md#exit-codes

# ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA

## Code Style

Follow all rules in AGENTS.md. Key project-specific conventions:
- Function calls and enum values: exactly one qualifier (e.g., `move_card::run()`)
- Struct/enum type names: zero qualifiers (e.g., `BattleState`, not `battle::BattleState`)
- No `pub use` declarations
- No code in `mod.rs`/`lib.rs` except module declarations
- No `use` declarations inside function bodies

## Code Review

Review your work against @rules_engine/docs/lattice/appendix_code_review.md.

Critical points:
- Expected errors → `LatticeError`; system errors → `panic!` with reason
- Write high-quality, non duplicative tests
- Create high-quality, useful logs via `tracing`
- Functions < 50 lines, files < 500 lines
- Aggressively refactor code to remove duplication

2. Create git commit with detailed description and a '# Manual Testing
   Instructions' commit message section (< 10 lines) with information about

## Scope

- **Text Formatter**: Human-readable plain text output
- **JSON Formatter**: Structured serde serialization for `--json` mode
- **Pretty Formatter**: Visual trees and colored output using color theme
- Consistent document reference format: `<id>: <name> - <description> [<type>]`

## Implementation Notes

- Create an `OutputFormat` enum or trait to abstract formatting
- JSON output should use serde_json with consistent field naming
- Pretty formatter should use Unicode box-drawing characters for trees
- Handle long descriptions with truncation and ellipsis
